results.title: The Door
results.creator_credit: Josie Keys, Anne Pratten, Jo-Anne McGowan and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A bedroom door becomes the focus of a teenage girl’s battle with her insensitive stepfather to reclaim the simpler relationship she remembers sharing with her mother. Stars Barry Otto and Penne Hackforth-Jones. Original format 16mm.

results.title: One hundred a day
results.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong, Alan Marshall and AFTRS
results.brief_description: In this highly acclaimed short by the director of ‘My Brilliant Career’ (1979) and ‘Oscar and Lucinda’ (1997), a young girl is forced to continue working at her machine all day in a 1930s shoe factory after a visit to a backyard abortionist. Cast features Rosalie Fletcher, Eve Wynne, Jenee Walsh, Beth Child, Virginia Partingale, Sue Piggott. Based on the short story ‘How beautiful are thy feet’ by Alan Marshall. Original format 16mm/black and white.

results.title: Peel
results.brief_description: A red-headed family’s drive in the countryside begins an intrigue of awesome belligerence and obstinacy. This short student drama from the director of ‘The Piano’ (2003) was the winner of the Palme d’Or for best short film at Cannes in 1986. Original format 16 mm/colour.

results.title: Cherith
results.creator_credit: Shirley Barrett, Francine Penrose and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Not being able to speak in tongues can be embarrassing at the very best of times. But if you are the only member of the congregation who cannot, and you are the daughter of a dynamic Revivalist preacher like Pastor Howard Spong - it’s even more distressing. And that’s just one of Cherith’s problems. This is a serious (and satirical) comedy about fundamentalist religion. This distinguished piece of film making, with a great script, direction and performance, won Best Short Fiction Film, AFI Awards in 1988.

results.title: Caravan park
results.creator_credit: Phil Noyce, Anthony Buckley and AFTRS
results.brief_description: When their car breaks down on the way to Queensland, a family is forced to take up residence at a caravan park while the father tries to earn enough money to get the car repaired. Much of the film is seen through the eyes of their young son as he comes to realise some of the complexities of his parents’ relationship. Great realist film from the director of ‘Patriot Games’ (1992), ‘The Bone Collector’ (1999) and ‘Rabbit-Proof Fence’ (2002). Based on the story by John Emery. Photography by Tom Cowan, editing by Anthony Buckley and production assistant, Gillian Armstrong. Original Format 16mm/black and white.

results.title: The Bus trip
results.brief_description: Ever gone on a trip and thought that maybe you left the oven on at home? In this entertaining film these kinds of speculations turn a simple cross country bus trip into a nightmare. Original Format 35mm/colour.
results.description: Ever gone on a trip and thought that maybe you left the oven on at home? In this entertaining film these kinds of speculations turn a simple cross country bus trip into a nightmare. Original Format 35mm/colour.

results.creator_credit: Darcy Yuille, Leesa Kahn and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Welcome to the world of Car Park - a multi-layered absurdist satire on the nature of relationships, communication and finding a parking space when you need one.

results.title: Birthday boy
results.creator_credit: Sejong Park, Andrew Gregory and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Korea 1951 - little Manuk is playing on the streets of his village and dreaming of life at the front where his father is a soldier. He returns home to find a parcel on the doorstep and, thinking it is a birthday present, he opens it. But its contents will change his life.
